_exec_summary.SummaryText:
U.S. Venture recognizes Safety Management as an essential element in providing a safe and secure place of employment for our associates as well as those people who  interact with our operations. Therefore, creating a safe work environment is extremely important. The corporate core values championed by our President, embraced by our Senior Leadership Team, encouraged by our Managers/Supervisors and pledged to our associates are: a) Caring Relationships, b) Entrepreneurial Spirit, c) Strategic Foresight, and d) High Performance. These 4 core values support our Safety and Health philosophy and management efforts. Interpersonal communications, problem solving, planning, and safety achievement have a direct relationship with the core values when applied to safety training, hazard assessment/investigation, post accident/incident recovery and generating solutions to potential risk exposures. U.S. Venture integrates Safety expectations as a part of Manager/Supervisors' responsibilities in order to create a meaningful daily presence during all work activity. Providing a safe work environment, reinforcing safe behaviors, and achieving meaningful safety results is a shared responsibility. Safety improvements, communication and recommendations from associates are critical to the productivity and success of U.S. Venture.



The U.S. Venture, Inc. - U.S. Oil Madison South Terminal (facility) is a bulk petroleum terminal that stores and distributes millions of gallons of refined petroleum products, including gasoline, diesel oil, denatured ethanol, biodiesel and fuel additives annually.  Recently, three 30 thousand-gallon butane storage vessels, butane blending equipment, and a rail butane delivering system was installed so that butane could be blended into gasoline.  The quantity of butane that is stored onsite exceeds the 10,000 pound threshold quantity, thus subjecting the facility to RMP requirements. 



The facility complies with the National Fire Protection Association (NFP

A)#58 (2011 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage and it is the facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal (including OSHA's Process Safety Management Regulation), state, and local laws/codes (including the State of Wisconsin's Department of Safety and Professional Services).  If a fire emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the McFarland Fire Department by calling 911, (distance to closest fire station from terminal is 1.5 miles by road) which may trigger involvement by Dane County Emergency Management, Wisconsin Emergency Management and/or City of Madison Hazardous Materials Team, as necessary.  Each of these Emergency Respnse Departments have and will continue to participate in informative tours at the facility that include an overview of the regulated process, the hazards of butane, and the safety systems that are in place. All facility personnel are 40-hour HAZWOPER certified and receive annual refresher hazardous materials training.



Dane County Emergency Management, in the event of a butane related emergency, will activate their Emergency Telephone Notification System. An authorized operator with the County can identify the affected neighborhood or region of the County and record a message that describes the situation and recommends the protective actions residents should take. The Emergency Telephone Notification system will automatically call out to all phone numbers in the County's database within the geographic area and deliver the recorded message.  If phone lines are busy, the system will attempt to redial those numbers a predetermined number of times to make contact.  If an answering machine picks up the call, the emergency message will be left on the machine.



The Risk Management Program (RMP) covers the butane blending system, including the associated piping, three storage vessels and butane rail cars. To date, the facility has not had an accident involving butane which has resulted in deaths, injuries, p

roperty/environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place. The facility emergency response plans are coordinated with the Fire Department and Dane County Emergency Management. 



Efforts to improve system safety include replacing all cable actuated Emergency Shutoff Valves with nitrogen driven pneumatic actuators. In the event of equipment malfunction resultiung in a release, a facility Emergency Shutdown (ESD) can be activated from a remote location at the facility closing vessel internal and truck bulkhead valves stopping the release rather than relying on human element to shut the valve that is cable driven.
